description.text:
Finishing parts for ERankLuck's Gigameter model. This is all very, very WIP until I've had a chance to assembly and fit things fully. As it stands, most of this is conceptual and untested. You've been warned!

Release 2 3/24/2017: Motor Base was split into Motor Shaft and Base for easy printing. Dome was redesigned to fit D-Shaft 3mm gearmotor. Dome parts successfully test fit against original model and Kit Kraft 89mm Dome.

Release 3 3/26/2017: Ears successfully converted to gear drive! Decided to write a quick printing guide, which you can find in the files and in the sketchup files .zip. I've updated the Ear and Servo mount model to clear the new ear gears, as well.

Release 4 4/1/2017: Not an April Fools joke. Two new models, left and right handle halves that incorporate a levered microswitch opening with mounting bosses, as well as a removal of the thumbwheel pot opening in the handles. At this point, all models have been tested and are on a fully assembled Gigameter. However, I will likely update this one more time to incorporate a speaker mount into the battery box cover, as it's a good place for one.

Release 5 4/11/2017: Added the speaker-grille battery box door and version 1.2 firmware for the Arduino. Also added Gigameter.winproj.zip, which is the project file and sounds required to program the WT588-16p prop sound chip used in this project. This includes the boot-up and running sounds.

Electronics ARE DONE - See the thread on GBFans Forums.

For now, I'm removing the WIP tag. I've fully built a Gigameter using these models, and it works great!

Printer Brand:

Robo 3D

Printer:

R1 ABS + PLA Model

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

200 Micron

Infill:

Varies

Notes:

FOLLOW THE PRINTING GUIDE.

Also, PRINT THE DOME BASE PLATE FIRST and test fit it against the Kit Kraft 89mm dome you'll be using to assemble this thing. You may have to size up your model to account for shrinkage (4-7% for PLA alone). Print EVERYTHING at that increased size so that it all lines up.

description.text:
Just what a bike needs...shelf space! I used PLA filament scraps to make these cool little shelves for my bike. I secured them to my adaptor bar with zip-ties (I made little channels for just such a thing). They are pretty dang secure on a 25.4mm bar with a rubber shim, but I have them on an old grip. I made little holes for securing stuff to the shelves via bungees and a slot for D straps. I use 2 of them to secure a water proof bluetooth speaker to my bike because tunes are very important.

Thanks for looking!

description.text: This is a cupcake designed to be 3d printed. The Blender file has both halves of the cupcake in it.
This a set of motor mounts for converting a Proxxon MF70 3-axis micro mill into a CNC mill. Watch it mill! http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=mGAO1evsziE

First, while printing the motor mounts, it's a good idea to do a google search with "mf70 cnc" and read some of the top results - many people have written better illustrated guides than fits here. Take off the handwheels from the mill. For X- and Y-axis this is done by loosening the nut at the far end of the axis (note! the Y-axis has left-handed threads) and pulling the axis out far enough so that you can punch out the holding pin. After this, the wheel comes off. For the Z-axis, loosen the 4 M3 bolts at the top, lift the whole spindle off the machine and loosen the nut under the top cover. Next thing needed is a coupler for each axis. The mounts are designed for 25mm long CNC couplers, available from Ebay. The mill end should be 4.5mm and the motor end 5mm. Since 4.5mm couplers are hard to find, a smaller diameter can be enlarged by drilling. In the original design, the handwheels themselves push against the bearings. Since they are not used after the CNC conversion, something else must be fitted on the shaft to perform the same function. Others have used brass collars, but I used 20mm long PTFE spacers (milled from 15mm rod) and have the couplers take the load instead of a separate collar. X- and Y-axis motor mounts can then be attached. They need longer self-tapping screws. 3.0x20 should be enough, but I wanted to use beefier screws, so I drilled the holes in the mill to 3mm and used four 3.5x22 stainless screws. The Z mount bolts on top of the mill with M3x35 screws. After the mounts are in place, the couplers attached and the axis nuts tightened to take out the play, the NEMA17 motors with 20mm shafts can be mounted with M3x12 screws. If everything still moves smoothly, it's time to hook up the electronics. It's possible to use RepRap electronics. The firmware should be configured to have 200x16 (16 being the microstepping value) steps per mm, maximum speed 300 mm/min and acceleration 1000 or 2000 mm/s*s. If not using endstops, software movement limits should be disabled. I'm using PyCAM for producing the G-code, and Marlin 1.0.0rc2 accepts it after a minor postprocessing step with a Perl script. The zipfile contains all the three STLs. The mf70-cnc.hs is the ImplicitCAD source code that will output all the STLs when run. The attached STLs have additionally been checked and rotated in netfabb. UPDATE 9.6.2012 I have gotten much better results from Heekscnc as the CAM program. I recommed it instead of PyCAM. It also needs some postprocessing for repraps and the script is attached. Also, the stock slide bearings should be replaced by MR126 ball bearings. These are a drop-in fit, but move the axis and the spacer so different motor mounts for X and Y are required. After shortening the spacers from 20 to 12 mm, the mounts marked with -mr126 can be used instead to get the proper alignment with the 25 mm couplers. UPDATE 18.6.2012 I replaced the MR126-variant X- and Y-mounts with 2mm longer ones, the fit proved to be a little too tight otherwise (the motor shafts extended too far into the couplers). UPDATE 4.9.2012 I crashed the mill into a work clamp and the X lead screw broke in two - even the NEMA17 motor was strong enough to break it. So I ordered some ball screws and will be publishing a ball screw upgrade sometime in the future. I'll also try to extend the Y work area at the same time. There are some modified versions out there with 86 mm Y travel instead of the default 46 mm. I also concluded that the PTFE spacers are too much of a hack. Don't use them, install some sort of stoppers on the screw shafts instead (something with a 4.5 mm center hole and a grub screw to lock it in place should work.)

comments.author: saifulnsr

comments.text: First you need to produce the GCODE file from Heekscnc. Then, if using Linux, you can run "./http://heeks2reprap.plheeks2reprap.pl < heeks.gcode > reprap.gcode" where the heeks.gcode is the output from Heekscnc. After this reprap.gcode can be loaded and run on the reprap firmware.

Might be better to put an job offer at http://forums.reprap.orgforums.reprap.org's "need stuff made" forum? http://forums.reprap.org/list.php?163http://forums.reprap.org/list....
comments.author: PacketNinja

comments.text: I'd also be interested in the script you are using to sanitize the G-code for marlin. I am pretty close to finishing a mill that will be running on Reprap electronics. What is it that Marlin doesn't like about your G-code?
comments.author: notloc

comments.text: Perl script is now attached. Main thing is that PyCAM's G-code contains lines with G0/G1 omitted, just beginning with a space and coordinates coming after that. It also has some codes that are not supported by RepRaps... spindle speed setting and things like that.
comments.author: notloc

comments.text: Great job. If I see correctly you are running the steppers from a Sanguinololu. That is a great little board. Marlin is great too and I have been working on getting the LCD capabilities in Marlin to work on 1284P Sanguinololu. Can you post the script that you created for it?
comments.author: Bluemetal

comments.text: Script attached. I'm using stock Sanguinololu, but I'm not sure if the normal stepper drivers are powerful enough (the maximum is apparently only 1A). It works, but the current setting seemed kind of finicky.

print_settings.Notes:: You may want to print it by turning model on the short side of the button and use a support, in this case all long parts will be printed lengthwise, they might be not so pretty after this, but who cares (it will be hidden inside a microwave). But it will be stronger in narrow spots. And you need this strength as you press the button every day.
print_settings.Printer:: Wanhao Duplicator i3 Plus

title: Panasonic Microwave Door Release button part number F80726Z30HAP
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
Made it in OpenScad, a simplified version of the original button. When the model was ready, I found exactly the same one over here http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:18867. I was caution about it, as the guide bushings are not sleek on that model, and the hole in the original button bushing mostly made for saving purpose (to use less plastic), and not used as a functional feature of the design. In 3D printing, we need to achieve a better adhesion between guide bushings and main platform of the button. So I have it solid in my case.

Special Notes:
1) Version 1 - Orignal Size
2) Version 2 - Clamp Size a bit increased, as when I tried to use an original size clamps, button was falling of the microwave. Probably because of the wearing and tearing inside the body.

Printer Brand:

Wanhao

Printer:

Wanhao Duplicator i3 Plus

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

100%

Notes:

You may want to print it by turning model on the short side of the button and use a support, in this case all long parts will be printed lengthwise, they might be not so pretty after this, but who cares (it will be hidden inside a microwave). But it will be stronger in narrow spots. And you need this strength as you press the button every day.

print_settings.Notes:: Zip Tie

description.text:
Bicycle Vase

I designed the clamp-on style vase last year for my daughters bike before I had my own 3D printer and knew anything about Thingiverse. Now that I have my own printer and understand how supports work I designed another version that uses a zip tie and does not require supports.

The clamp-on version is nice because it snaps on/off the bars very easily. Its designed to fit a 22mm diameter handle bar. The end of the clamp arms have grooves so it can be further secured with a rubber band. The zip tie version is not so easy to remove but it works on any size handle bar.

Printer:

Monoprice Select Mini

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Notes:

The Zip Tie version prints right side up and does not require supports.
The Clamp On version prints upside down and requires supports only on the end of the clamping arms.

title: Braille Dice
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text: 4, 6, 8, 10, 12, and 20 sided dice in braille. Letters a-t represent numbers 1-20. The entire braille cell has been included and recessed for orientation purposes. I also tried to put the bottom of the cell parallel to a side.

Printer:

Monoprice Maker Select

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

.2 mm

Infill:

20%

Notes:

Supports:
D4, D6: No supports.
D8, D10, D12: Supports.

Infill: They seem to roll pretty randomly at 20% infill, but can definitely be printed at 100% if you're worried about them not being random.

Resolution: The pictured prints were done at .3 mm before I knew better. I'd definitely recommend .2 mm or below.
Remove rafts, sand if desired, play.

Upon searching Thingiverse for braille stuff, I came across this d20: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:93798. I printed it out and even at the recommended 70%, it is still pretty big. So I designed a new one to save as much space as possible. Then the next logical extension was to make the rest of the dice set.

Designs have been tested and approved by my boyfriend, who is blind and a braille user.

comments.text: How should I print the D20? I tryed 2 times one with support and other with brim/skirt with 100% infill but is very bad at the bottom.

comments.text: On a glass. I'm printing in ABS

title: Turtle Beach X11 Left Earpiece Swivel

description.text: First project with CAD in a long time. Built this because my existing bracket broke.

I have not had this printed yet (I do not own a printer...yet) however I will have it printed soon enough to make sure it fits, etc. Plus I want my headset to work again.
The only after printing process you'll have to accomplish is three holes, 1 for where the wire goes through the round peg at the top (from the headband) and 2 more to push pegs in for where the bracket is mounted to the ear piece.
Any input is appreciated. This was built in FreeCad however I'm looking for better/easier ways. I've looked into OpenScad and I like the idea, however its also nice to have a gui at times.

comments.text:
This looks good. Is the X12 similar to the X11?
If so, I would add a channel for the wire, and the pegs on the X12 come from this piece going into the Headphone assembly.
It also looks like there might need to be more clearance between the top peg and the sides on top, but that's only from eyeballing it.

comments.text: I really like this design. Any chance you could remix it to take 3/8th inch nuts? I'm making a bunch for kids and the younger ones are having difficulty with the larger sizes. If you can't I completely understand. Thanks!
comments.author: Varuka

comments.text: I'm sorry for getting back to you so late I haven't really been checking the comments that much
comments.author: Varuka

comments.text: Do you mean make the whole design smaller or just the size of the holes for the nuts
comments.author: Varuka

comments.text: Just the hole for the nuts. An American 3/8 nut is 5 sixteenths of an inch on the outside flat to flat.
comments.author: cartermann14

comments.text: 5 sixteenths of an inch is really small, it's less than 1 centimeter. I can make it but it might look kinda weird with the nuts being 1/2 the size of the ones I'm using right now. Also it might effect the spinner because smaller but means less weight.
comments.author: Varuka

comments.text: Do you have a link to the nuts used? That seems like a very odd size of hex nut.
comments.author: justinds89

comments.text: Im stupid, I dont really know how to classify nuts based on size I was just measuring it with a ruler, but now that i look at the package it says 1/2" - 13
comments.author: justinds89

comments.text: Oh okay, that makes more sense haha. Was a bit confused as to what size hex nuts they were. Thanks.

print_settings.Notes:: Spiral Vase Mode

description.text:
These telescoping nesting screws are intended to be printed in spiral vase mode. They are fun to play with, you can use them as a giant telescoping screw, or like Russian Nesting Dolls.

Here is a video of it in action:

https://youtu.be/Fn-lfC774kw

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.2 layer height, .4 extrusion width

Infill:

None

Notes:
  • Spiral Vase Mode
  • 0.2 layer height
  • 2 bottom layers
  • no top layers
  • no infill
  • 0.4 extrusion width (it might hard to screw and unscrew at 0.5, which is the default for a 0.4 nozzle in most programs)
It's a circle extruded along a helix. The number is the size of the circle in tenths of a millimeter.

comments.text: How did you achieve the effect in the video?  Are these tubes slightly tapered so they catch inside one another?  When I spin my tube they all fall apart.
comments.author: Stoutlimb

comments.text: When I print them they have a solid bottom layer to catch on when when I'm collapsing them, but I just have to be careful when extending them to keep them from falling apart.
comments.author: Stoutlimb

comments.text: I came upon your design because I was planning on designing something similar for a linear actuator.  It's good to see what other people are doing.  I agree there is a lot of difficulty with a design that catches, it's very tricky indeed, especially with vase mode limiting what can and cannot be designed.  I have tried many catch time mechanisms and so far none work perfectly, but I'm closing in on one.
comments.author: somewhat_brave

comments.text: I think you could make a catch that works if you "print in place", so they don't have to be assembled. But that would mean you can't print in spiral vase mode, which means it wont extend as smoothly.
comments.author: Stoutlimb

comments.text:
Victory!
https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2687374
comments.author: somewhat_brave

comments.text: There's a way to do it in spiral mode, I just know it. It's extremely difficult so far.  I've spent days in man-hours iterating my design, and I'm still not there, but close.  I'm a perfectionist, and I need this for my robot, so I won't stop till I've got something good.  Also, anything more than single wall vase mode will end up too thick for what I'm going to use it for.  I'll share when I've got it.
comments.author: somewhat_brave

comments.text: The tubes are not hollow as shown in your video. It this correct?
comments.author: Luddite

comments.text: In the stl they're solid. You have to print it in spiral vase mode to make it hollow.
comments.author: Luddite

description.text:
This small minimalist box holds my visit cards when I demo the printer. It is just clipped on top of the protruding walls of my ultimaker but should work wherever the thickness is about 6 mm.  
The scad file is provided in case you want other dimensions, I do not think it is worth for the verbose customizer.

Print it upsde down!  
You can set a very low infill and wall thickness.

author: skfong

title: Lee No. 19 Shell Holder for 9mm Luger - Reloading Essentials

description.text:
This is an exact model of the standard Lee Precision No. 19 Shell Holder commonly used for reloading 9mm Luger. This differs slightly from the one used on the lee turret presses as that one has an extension on the bottom allowing it to be captured by the press ram.

This was modeled and rendered in Autodesk Fusion 360. Available in fusion 360 Filetype (.F3D) for modification if needed, as a Step file (.STP) for importing to other CAD programs, and as an STL file for printing directly.

Please note this model was not optimized for printing and a plastic part would likely not work in a press, as the forces subjected would likely break the plastic in short order. This model is only for reference purposes. Please support our reloading manufacturers and purchase Lee Precision products. They are an excellent company.

author: acastro

description.text:
10/4/17 Update: New Designs! Now the print time is shorter, it's easier to use, the sleeves snap into place, and the pin is a separate piece so it won't break and ruin everything, wohoo! I will be uploading sleeves of the exact length of paper sleeves to make sorting the coins even easier.

The second version of my coin sorter, solving all of the issues of the previous version while also making it smaller and more compact. The video shows the assembly as well as usage of the mechanism.

Here is the download link for the CAD file: http://a360.co/2nO4DOE
If you are using Fusion 360, you should be able to go into the user parameters and edit the coin dimensions for it to work with your currency

https://youtu.be/sS2p0F2tEec

comments.text:
Great design. Works perfectly once I put hopper in correct position.
I have coin sorting plastic sorters from the dollar store. They are just cylinders with a wide mouth and a slit at the top. You scoop coins in, when the coins reach the top thats the exact amount to roll. The excess coins fall out of the slit in top. So once the coins fall out the slit, you have the exact amount to then roll. Thats the last step this design needs. Coin cylinders that hold the correct amount to roll once filled.
I can post the depths of the cylinders if you want. I figure u make the base the size of the longest cylinder. Then spacers for cylinders that are smaller. But you'll have depths needed to have correct amounts for rolling.

comments.text: This is a brilliant design, but there's one thing I don't understand: why not make the coin sleeves the right height to hold the right number of coins to roll? This is called a US coin sorter, and it does that quite well, but its utility is limited to sorting only, not counting. I understand that if you made the sleeves the right height, they wouldn't all be the same height, but as long as the holder is the height of the tallest sleeve, you could just sort until the sleeves were full, take out the sleeve, knock any excess coins off the top, and be left with the exact right number of coins to put in a roll. Quarters work fine to roll straight out of the sleeve, but $1.80 in nickles and $0.46 in pennies doesn't make a lot of sense. Could this happen? It would be absolutely awesome if this could happen. Also it would more than double the utility of the design, because then I wouldn't have to manually add a couple coins here and there in order to make a full roll. Like I said, overall, this is an awesome design, but it could be so much better if I didn't still have to add coins manually.

comments.text: There is a flaw in the hopper. The inside of the female mount on the hopper is supposed to have an indentation (you can see the corresponding male bump on the base) but in the STL, it's not there. So, you try and force the hopper on and you will break off the mount point. This is a very advanced design in fusion360, I haven't a clue how to fix it.
comments.author: Koobs

comments.text: I have a slight design modification suggestion as well. Round or slope the points of the top of the base that point against the rotation of the spinner, to avoid them snagging the spinner. When doing a test fit of the spinner with the base while the hopper is printing, these points on each coin collection area keep catching the holes in the spinner. Sanding them down a little bit seems to be working.

comments.text:
No problem. I figured you would rather know than not. One quick question. When wrapping coins to turn in to the bank, the amounts are
Quarters - $10, Pennies - $0.50, Nickels $2 and Dimes $5. On your sleeves, the Quarters are correct, Pennies are only $0.46, Nickels are $1.80 and Dimes are $5.20. It occurred to me that you could increase the height of the sleeves (and probably base) slightly to allow the tallest stack of coins to be consistent with the amount that the bank wants in each wrapper and then adjust the thickness of the base of the other sleeves so that all the amounts would come out right. Nothing that needs to be done but something you might want to think about if there is ever a v3.
comments.author: Pentland_Designs

comments.text: I have created an unofficial V3 in which I made the sleeves hold the correct amounts, as well as a couple of other minor tweaks and changes. It is posted as a remix of this design.

author: skfong

description.text:
This remix makes an already great 3D printed bottle opener a little better with the addition of a captive magnet that lets you stick it on the fridge and helps keep track of loose caps.

I added a small extension "tab" to the magnet cavity to provide a visual indication to pause the print to insert the magnet. With 0.3mm resolution it would print (4) layers with this "tab" before the bridge starts.

The project uses 3/4" ceramic magnets I purchased at Lowe's. You only need one(1) magnet per opener.
https://www.lowes.com/pd/The-Hillman-Group-3-4-in-Ceramic-Disc-Magnet/3115767

description.text:
Since we bought our house this frame has been missing and I've never seen a replacement in the shops. So when my 3D printer arrived this was first job on the list!

It's designed to interference fit snug with the switch, especially the nub clip-ins over the screws

For improvement: If anything it's a little bit too tight, I think the nubs are slightly out of best position. Also, not super keen on the colour! I've had a suggestion of wood filament, which is probably best in my case as I doubt 'old ivory yellow' is available.

Printer:

Kodama Trinus

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.3mm

Infill:

100%

Notes:

To print on my Kodama (only 120x125mm build space) I oriented it at ~45deg. It will just fit provided there are no rafts etc.

author: LitterBug

description.text:
This is just a laser support I designed so I don't have to keep moving the laser around every time I engrave something. It fits this laser but I made it with the exact measurements so you might want to scale it up 1 or 2 mm otherwise it might be a bit tight.
https://www.aliexpress.com/item/500mw-405NM-focusing-blue-purple-laser-module-engraving-with-TTL-control-laser-tube-diode-protective-googles/32562052620.html?spm=2114.13010608.0.0.gidgN3

Printer:

Anet A8

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.3

Infill:

70%

Notes:

Print it in the orientation that is present in the picture, this is because it uses less filament for the supports.
I designed this to use the least amount of filament possible so there are some parts which are a bit thin but this is for holding a laser module when it's not in use, not a ship so it should be fine.
If you find that it's a bit tight just take a lighter and heat up the corners on the inside and push the laser in, that should solve the problem.
FreeCad

description.text:
This is a simple extender piece for Illis' Nerf Magazine http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:152647. It has two flanged ends, so you can bolt it between the top and bottom part of Illis' magazine. You add as many of these as you like if you have the right length spring.

People like me with "hobby" grade printers don't have the Z-height to print SCHEMENKE's larger magazines - http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1131004. (I do use SCHEMENKE's Slider v2 though).

You can see my extender piece in the photo in betwween the pieces of Illis' design. The pictured spring is from an off-brand 12 dart mag that I broke.

Please post photos of your makes - Its cool to see what you print + I like to learn how people's print settings affect my designs.

0.28mm resolution is a little coarse for the slider part. It does work, but next time I will print the slider at 0.8 so it runs smoother. Nobody wants a mag jam when there are zombies about!

comments.text: There was nothing keeping your double ended piece aligned other than two bolts. I added the same alignment supports as the bottom piece and filled the release catch hole. print_settings.Notes:: Support is only needed in a few pieces, but it should be pretty evident.  Remember that this will take some abuse, so use at least 3 perimeters and decent infill.

description.text:
My kids wanted to take stuff up and down the treehouse constantly, and instead of watching them fall down a ladder with a bucket of rocks (really) I started working on a solution. The dumbwaiter is currently installed on a treehouse, but is appropriate in any venue where 3/4 inch EMT conduit would not be unsightly. The "car" is still a work in progress and will likely evolve. Right now it's just made of plywood with PVC (I think 1 inch) on the rails. There is potential improvements in the future to the car itself. Also pulling the ball chain (even with the approximate 4:1 mechanical advantage) is a little tough for young ones, so I'll probably add a crank at some point.

EDIT: I designed and printed the crank arm (see added STL file). Definitely an improvement and now even the 2 year old can bring things up and down.

Printer:

QIDI Tech I

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.2mm

Infill:

35% or more

Notes:

Support is only needed in a few pieces, but it should be pretty evident. Remember that this will take some abuse, so use at least 3 perimeters and decent infill.

Installation

Printing is easy. Putting this together is less straight forward. The set is designed to be flexible for a variety of mounting, which means it's not convenient for any of them. The basic gist is that first you have to create the two horizontal surfaces on which the brackets will mount. Then determine the length of your vertical pieces of conduit. It will have to be continuous, so you're probably limited to 10 ft. Next is attaching the brackets to the horizontal surfaces. Since the screws go in diagonally, I included drill templates you can print to guide a a 1/8" bit for pilot holes. I find it useful to have the car built first to define the spacing between the conduit rails. The rails are secured to the brackets with zip ties.

Once the rails are done, then the horizontal conduit at the top is sized to be long enough to span the brackets and the ball chain cog and guide. Pictures show how the parts are installed on the top piece of conduit. The bushings and chain cog are secured to the conduit by drilling a hole in the conduit in the correct place and putting a #8 screw through the provided hole.

The car is connected by a rope (I used paracord) to the car and through the provided holes in the bushings. The routing, number of bushings, knots, etc. are situation dependent. #6 ball chain is used to drive the cog. Installation is by wrapping the chain around the cog and then sliding the guide over. The pictures are useful in understanding this. I also split open one ball and spliced the chain so it was continuous and doesn't have the connector in the loop.

Amazon

"Roman copy of a Greek Bronze by Cresilas of ca. 440 BC.

In mythology, Amazons were mighty female warriors who fought against the Greeks. These sensual but fierce women offered classical sculptors the opportunity to depict the bared female breast. Statue reproduces a famous Greek original depicting an amazon wounded beneath her right breast. It was one of several statues of Amazons entered in a sculptors competition at the temple of Artemis at Ephesus in western Asia Minor, about 440 BC. The sculptor of this entry is believed to have been Cresilas. According to the ancient writer Pliny, the contest was judged by the sculptors themselves, and each voted for his own first and gave second place honors to a work by Polkyleitos, making him the winner. Cresilas received third prize."

Shot in the Walters Art Museum in Baltimore.

title: 30mm Screwless Fan Mount for Monoprice Mini Select Controller Board

description.text:
Have a Monoprice Select Mini 3D Printer? Want some extra cooling for your controller board? Hate or don't have any screws or standoffs? Have an extra 30mm fan? Then this bracket is for you. A mashup of a Thingiverse design and one I found on Hackaday, this extremely rudimentary fan holder nevertheless holds a fan over the controller board and therefore does its job.

What you need:
A 30mm fan
A Monoprice MP Select Mini 3D printer
Some rigid filament of some kind

Here's an FAQ for the curious:

Q: There are other perfectly good, far more attractive solutions to extra cooling for the controller board, like this: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1867169 Why did you do this?
A: That one requires long screws. Another nice one requires standoffs. I don't have those.

Q: Wouldn't a 40mm fan be better?
A: Almost certainly, but I do not have one. I ordered one from AliExpress, but who knows when that will arrive. The 30mm spare got here sooner.

Q: OK, fine, then why not use this 30mm fan version, based on the same thing you ripped off? https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1697704
A: One, I did not feel like using screws. Two, I did not see that until I was writing this FAQ.

Q: Doesn't this look kinda ghetto?
A: Yes, but I made it in TinkerCAD because I cannot figure out any other CAD software. It works and nobody will see it.

Q: What did you use to print this?
A: Bamtack white PLA at 200 degrees on blue tape, no heated bed.

Q: Which one did you rip off that was not on Thingiverse?
A: You can find it at https://hackaday.io/project/12371/files

Printer:

Monoprice MP Select Mini

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

.2625 layer height

Infill:

40% rectilinear

Notes:

You probably want to print this upside down so there are fewer supports. Also, in the pics I did minimal post-processing. Basically, I just tore off the supports. So I am sure you can get it looking way nicer.

description.text:
This is a set of handles for an enclosure door where the doors swing out. The intent is to insert magnets in each handle so that when the door is closed, the magnets hold them together.

Update: I've also included a 3 inch high one with the same hole sizes. The magnets I use are the 10 pcs rare earth magnets from Harbor Freight. (http://www.harborfreight.com/10-piece-rare-earth-magnets-67488.html)

The holes for mounting are .149" diameter holes designed for tapping out 10-24 or 10-32 (Sorry, not a metric guy, been working in imperial too long).

IMPORTANT NOTE: Before you glue the magnets in, MAKE SURE that the north pole in the first handle is oriented to the South pole in the other handle, OTHERWISE, you will have a door OPENER, not a door CLOSER.

Printer:

Monoprice Maker Select Plus

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

200 micron

Infill:

25%

Notes:

I printed these upside down, with 15 skirt outlines 3 layers thick. The top of these has a nice flat surface, and doesn't require support generation if printed in this orientation.
I used MOI3d design. One of the best organic design programs I've found.

description.text:
Another OpenSCAD creation, composed of a number of vertical fingers made from a twisting extrusion of an ellipse, capped with a rim and base composed of a rotated ellipse.

OK, forget the math. I was playing around and hit on something that reminded me of a Grecian column. Playing with sizes and angles, I formed it into at first a bowl and then this cup. The OpenSCAD code is too much of a mess for the customizer, with lots of numbers that I kept adjusting to shape it just so. Feel free to tinker with the angles and sizes to make your own creation.

Printer:

Mini

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2mm

Infill:

33%

Notes:

I did this in solid white PETG without supports, sliced with AlephObject's version of Cura.

If you decide to go to a higher resolution you might want to step up the $fn values in OpenSCAD and re-render. As it stands, the STL I published took 17 minutes on a 3.2GHz i7, so factor in your need for patience.

title: Chevy S10 Lug Nut Cover (With Test Iterations)

description.text:
This is a test lug nut cover that I created mainly to test how the threads print. If they are correct I'll modify the cover to be more than just a cylinder.

-UPDATED- Second iteration uploaded. Thinner wall, deeper hole, and scaled to 101% to counter ABS shrink. (successful threads).

-UPDATED- Third iteration uploaded. Threads are good, so adjusted model to look like stock S10 lug nut cover. It's not quite OEM, but dang close!

-UPDATED- I added the Fusion 360 file as well as an obj file for those interested in modifying this design. I could not find the original file, so I remade it. It should be very close to the original.

-UPDATED- I made a Chevy bow tie cutout in the face of the cover and included the bow tie as well. If you have a dual extrusion printer the models should fit together as is. I do not, so I will be printing the parts out separately and pressing them together after. I will add pictures once I have printed this newest update.

-UPDATED- I realized that the bow tie was backwards, so I corrected that. I also added a version of the lug nut cover and the bow tie insert with fillets to make them easier to press together for us non-dual extruder folks. If you are using a dual extruder printer use the models without the fillets.

Printer Brand:

MakerBot

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.2mm

Infill:

100%

Threads on the first model are a little tight. Threads on second model are correct, but snug enough that it should not come off on its own. Final model may need to be threaded on with the lug wrench the first time. I was able to screw it on by hand the second time, but still used the lug wrench to snug it against the wheel.

Designed in AutoDesk Fusion 360.
Original Model: 30mm diameter, 50mm tall cylinder with a 40mm tall hole that is threaded to 24mm (M24-2).

Second Iteration: 27mm diameter, 50mm tall cylinder with a 46mm tall hole that is threaded to 24mm (M24-2) then scaled to 101% to account for ABS shrinkage.

Third iteration: 28mm diameter, 19.5mm tall cylinder with a 16.5mm tall hole that is threaded to 24mm (M24-2) with 3mm worth of the cylinder beveled down to meet a 19mm hexagon that is 9.5mm tall (overall height is 29mm).

Fourth iteration: created a bow tie emblem and cut it from the face of the existing model.

This is a little protection for an outdoor PL lamp.
I made 3 versions, no big changes. I think all works good.

It is a simple project, you can use the settings you think it is better.

Everyone has added things to place in the scrying pool. I thought I would provide something that would happen if things went wrong in the pool or the player characters thought they needed to destroy the pool. Yes, I know it is more stones than would be there with the section of wall gone, but this isn't reality. I wanted to make it more obvious and yes it is possible it wouldn't be a pile of stones. it is a remix from Dutch Mogul's scrying pool http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2016098.

Printer Brand:

PowerSpec

Printer:

PowerSpec 3D Pro

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

10%

comments.text: Would you mind explaining how you modified the model?
comments.author: industriald

comments.text: Not sure exactly what your question is? Do you mean how is it different or how did I do it? If you mean how is it different, then the answer is that I destroyed a portion of the original side and then added stones to simulate being destroyed from within or the other side of the pool. If you mean how did I create it. Then it was a rather involved method of using different software to subtract and then patch the side. I then used blender to also do some sculpting of the subtracted portions to add a jaggedness. I then added stones that were already available from other creations and created some of my own. I then cleaned up some of the work with patching.
comments.author: industriald

comments.text: Sorry, yes I was curious as to the software and method used to modify the existing model.
comments.author: melabam

comments.text: Love it! I'll have to print one for my table.
comments.author: dutchmogul

comments.text: Well I am not even close to your talent level and if you feel you can do a more realistic destroyed scrying pool and want to I won't be offended. I just needed one and this looked to be the best I could do given the time I had to do it.

title: Anet A8 Offset Filament Guide - Extruder Mounted

description.text:
This is just another filament guide for the Anet A8. I created this for a very specific purpose. I'm using the wonderful extruder fan modification from user nicolaidiz (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2037833) as well as the X axis cable chain (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1905344) this means that I only had two screws left over to fit a filament guide on the extruder housing!

I wanted/needed something to keep the filament straight, and keep it off the cable chain, and use the only two scews I had left as most mount to either all 4 screws, or the outside screws on the left. So I whipped this up real quick.

It's not quite exactly how I want it, and plan on tweaking it a little bit more but for now it works!

Printer:

Anet A8

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.20

Infill:

20%

Notes:

Nothing fancy. Supports not needed, .20 works best. Infill at least 20% anything higher is a waste of filament but hey it's your filament not mine!
Remove the two screws from the bearing block, add the filament guide, put screws back. That simple!
123D Design (original file included in downloads)

description.text:
The Kliment Voroshilov (KV) tanks were a series of Soviet heavy tanks, named after the Soviet defense commissar and politician Kliment Voroshilov and used by the Red Army during World War II. The KV series were known for their extremely heavy armour protection during the early part of the war, especially during the first year of the German invasion of the Soviet Union.
KV-1S â A lighter variant of late 1942 with higher speed, but thinner armour. A new, smaller, cast turret and redesigned rear hull were used. 1370 were built.

author: coogle

title: Mendelmax under carriage power supply mount

description.text:
A few mounting clips to clip a common 12 power supply to the inside of the mendelmax frame under the carriage
NB this protrudes 10mm under the Mendelmax. You need to raise your mendelmax on feet of some type.
I used http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:15880 I have added 'Fixed' stl files, these have been passed threw netfab

This is designed to clip onto the Mendelmax t-slot, no nut insertions are required. The power supply is like this one on e-bay http://www.ebay.com/itm/High-Quality-12V-30A-360W-Switch-Power-Supply-Driver-LED-Lights-Strips-/150790646680?pt=LH_DefaultDomain_0&hash=item231bd2ab98 Power Supply Dimensions 215 x 113 x 50 mm Print two side clips and one end clip. Screw the side clips to the side of the power supply in the highest set of holes (only on one side of my power supply) Place the power supply on the side it is going to clip onto away from the end where it will finish up. Angle the power supply so the lower clips clip into place solidly. Tilt power supply to level position and top clip into place. Clip end clip into t-slot using same lower then level out technique. Slide power supply down to correct position to attach end clip and screw in place.

comments.text: Slic3r keeps saying that your geometry is broken.
comments.author: zanahade

comments.text: always run all stl's threw http://cloud.netfabb.com/http://cloud.netfabb.com/ many program generate stl that are broken. And Slicer is very picky about broken stl's
comments.author: zanahade

comments.text: I see! Thanks! I am still very much new at this :-)

description.text: This is a 1/4" ratchet extender. I was working on my Lennox furnace to replace the ignitor, but I couldn't reach the screws, so I designed this to help. It gave me just the right amount of extra length to hold the ignitor and the wrench to be able to tighten the screws. I hope this helps someone else.

Printer:

Rafts:

No

author: andy2203

description.text:
This is a sample swatch for metal infused filaments. It is designed for convenient polishing of its 30mm square flat side, revealing the filament's sheen.

NOTE: I did not spend the time to coarse sand my pieces level before polishing. I used 100, 200, 400 grit sandpaper followed by Gator step 1, 1500 grit and finally step 3 polishing sandpaper. I then buffed the pieces with a cloth. Shown from left to right are colorfabb's brassfill, copperfill and bronzefill.

It looks as though, with more work, a crude mirror finish is possible.

title: Dry Fire Block for Umarex Colt Commander BB/Airsoft

description.text: This handy little piece allows you to safely dry-fire your Umarex Colt Commander BBgun without fear of damaging the mechanism. Since all Umarex 1911 style models are based on basically the same design, this may work for any or all of them including the Airsoft versions. I have only tested it with the BB version. It is tiny and only takes a few minutes to print so try it out and report back if it works on another model.

Printer Brand:

Prusa

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.2

Infill:

75%

Notes:

PLA filament works fine but if you have some nylon filament that would be even better. ABS would also work.

If printed 100% scale, this is a very tight fit and works perfectly in my case. You may want to try slightly varying the x or y scale to adjust the fit. Too loose is bad since it pops out when used but too tight can mean difficulty in removing and you may need a small screwdriver to pry it out.

It only takes a tiny amount of filament and prints in a few minutes so experiment.

description.text:
My daughter wanted prize trophies, but didn't want the fleur de lis, so I told her no problemo!

Nice design, thanks for the upload!

My daughter asked me if I could print a chair big enough for her to sit in. Challenge accepted. See http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:218782 To do it, I had to design this snap fit joint for the legs and posts. I thought people might be interested in the joint itself to play with. If I start using this more often or if there's interest, I might clean up the OpenSCAD code and turn it into an easy to use library. FYI, my daughter loved the chair, but quickly grew out if it. Now she uses it as a chair for her stuffed animals.
Sliced at Medium quality in Makerware (0.2 mm layer height, 10% infill). Printed on a Replicator 2 in PLA.

description.text:
I have tested this design and all fits well its made for PLA. Please leave comments and suggestions in the comments I'd be happy to hear from you.

This has been remade from my original design as there where shrinkage issues with the LCD hole and the screw mounts not printing properly due to poor design.

Please leave comments for any improvements you may want or any issues you come across when you print it.

This is for the CTC i3 pro 3D printer LCD to move it form the top of the printer into a separate box.

**Edit:
Final design, as you can see from the picture all works well, I have made final changes to the layout to better fit the LCD PCB into the case, I used the screws and nuts form the original LCD plywood board to mount it into the case, I then used 4 counter sunk 10mm screws in the back to put the back cover on.

Will add some cable clips later on to keep the ribbon cables in order.

print_settings.Notes:: Use ABS or PET-G to deal with the outdoor weather.
print_settings.Printer:: Wanhao Duplicator i3 V2

description.text:
The flip up door on my genie intellicode garage door keypad broke and after contacting genie their advice was to buy a new one. I decided to see what i could do and after about 4-5 iterations this is what i came up with. This is printed using PET-G so good heat and sun resistance and strong. Even with only 10% infill it is incredibly strong I used superglue to attach it to the body and the bevelled edges make it a snap to get the cover on.

For your own sake do not try to put the cover on until the glue has had plenty of time to set.

This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online https://tinkercad.com/things/gbKddffgJfy

Version 3 Derivative:
2020 UNIVERSAL SPOOL HOLDER SLIM VERSION V3

Included is a bowden tube guide to help with guiding your filament guide tube. It is setup to work with the 2020 Universal Spool Holder with two feed tubes. In the top center there are two holes to accommodate the pneumatic fittings that the bowden tube inserts into and locks into place. You will need to drill out the center of the pneumatic fitting so the bowden tube can slide completely through and the tube can take the turn into the arms. The pneumatic fitting will lock the tube into place.

title: Adafruit Si7021 Sensor Case
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Probably not going to be a popular one as I don't see many people using this exact sensor in their projects. I'm actually impressed with the little guy, and for the price, it serves its purpose. Using it to measure the temperature & relative humidity around my printer. Thus far, the readings have been pretty darn accurate.

Anyways, this is a small, simple case. You pop the Si7021 into the case (press fit so it isn't going anywhere), then press on the front grill. Could probably use a little tweaking on the sizes, but once I put it together relatively easy, I said the heck with it, maybe someone else will want to modify it if needed.

Using it with OctoPrint/Octopi. So I created a plugin that will print it's readings on the nav bar of OctoPrint.

https://github.com/nixternal/OctoPrint-Si7021

Printer:

Prusa i3 MK2

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

No

Resolution:

.2

Infill:

20%

author: nixternal

print_settings.Notes:: I used PLA for this part, but you may want to use a higher temperature material, depending on the location and the temperatures near this fan.  I tried using 25% infill but one of the legs broke off, so I would use a higher infill to prevent this from happening.

title: 35mm Fan Mount for cooling 3D printer ramps board

description.text: I designed this 35mm fan mount to clip into the 2020 rail on my Folger Tech Kossel 2020 3D printer. This mounts under the printer to cool the Ramps board. I used M3 bolts I believe they were 20mm long, but you may need longer depending on how deep your fan is. I didn't have to use nuts on the back because the bolts threaded right into the plastic.

Printer:

description.text:
Easy to print, just use a few lines of brim and you are good.

I printed slow 30mm/s and at 0.15mm but only because I used meltink3d glow and it is an incredibly hard filament and will just strip if you try and print too fast. That said the finish is 2nd to none and well... it glows. (blue is glow, grey is raptor pla, printed at .2mm and 60mm/s)
Grey is the original with holes too big and some symmetry errors that I fixed, also shrank the holes down to 22mm from 22.148mm.

Easy to spin due to the shape and at 7.6mm thick its on the weighty side and spins for days.
(2:20) with the right bearings.

print_settings.Notes:: I made mine with .25mm resolution and It came out perfect. Made with PLA at 215 ext - 68 bed temps. Infill around 12% is suitable, but 10% should suffice and 20% would be the highest I would go, unless you are trying to stop a train. Print the parts with the pegs/legs upward. Use a brim if needed, it could help with adhesion issues for both parts. Due to the nature of the model, stringing between the mount legs most likely will occur. This does not mean your printer is bad/malfunctioning.

description.text:
UPDATED to v1.2 04/29/17

A simple two piece, easy printing, easy assembling housing for a Raspberry Pi with a 120mm fan mount above it. Pi 3's run quite hot, and this housing provides plenty of cooling performance as it is open air, has perforation under CPU area, and well, there's a 120mm fan blowing above it. Specifically made to fit an RPI 3 model B with it's own case already, as there's some tolerance between the supports for the pi's placement area and the pi itself. Designed to fit snug with slim cases like http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1415895 (the one I'm using), but will not fit much bigger. However, it will nicely fit the naked pi. The screw holes for the fan mount are specifically made for M3 screws as that's all I had around, but I am providing the DWG's so you can edit if you desire larger screws (or just drill larger holes). The screw holes for the fan should be snug enough to fit the screws without nuts, but you can use nuts for a more secure fit. Made in AutoDesk AutoCAD 2017 and auto-repaired in Autodesk Netfabb Premium 2017.

Todo:

  • remake bottom in AutoCAD (lost it somewhere)
  • make bottom perforated for better cooling
  • make looser tolerances for pegs
  • Make fan mount inner-perimeter circular for more airflow
  • Make something better

Printer:

XYZ Da Vinci 1.0 w/E3D v6

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.25mm - 0 .1mm

Infill:

10% - 20%

Notes:

I made mine with .25mm resolution and It came out perfect. Made with PLA at 215 ext - 68 bed temps. Infill around 12% is suitable, but 10% should suffice and 20% would be the highest I would go, unless you are trying to stop a train. Print the parts with the pegs/legs upward. Use a brim if needed, it could help with adhesion issues for both parts. Due to the nature of the model, stringing between the mount legs most likely will occur. This does not mean your printer is bad/malfunctioning.

Get rid of stringing/flaws

Run an x-acto knife around the edges and pegs to remove major flaws and/or strings.
Easy print! Both (identical) halves print without support material, and snap together with a little force to create a solid final part.

title: autobed leveling servo-mount/holder | for i3 rework | ch1t0 extruder

description.text:
I needed a servo-mount for my i3 rework in order to use autobed leveling. This is the outcome. It is not 100% accurate because i measured everything with a ruler. You may have to use a little force to push the servo through its slot. But it worked for me.  
The i3 rework is based on ch1t0's extruder, so if you are using this kind of extruder it should work as well.  
You also need Zennmasters Z-probe holder and maybe longer bolts for your X-Carriage + two nuts

-Print this part.
-Print Zennmasters Z-probe holder.
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:222861
-Make your servo fit into the holder, tighten with screws.
-Mount the Z-probe holder (with your endstop) on your servo.
-Place the assembly behind the hotend by mounting it to the X-Carriage bolts, tighten with nuts. Have a look at the pictures i guess it's easier to understand it when you see it. For any other instructions(code changes etc.) follow Zennmasters videos:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=awsI9bMndJA
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=6msLOR_EfKc
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=YpiOsetkIRg

print_settings.Notes:: The hotend bracket goes on the top of the carriage using the existing screws. Just mount them the other way around (with the nyloc M3 nuts on the front). Use a zip tie on the left to secure your hotend wires into position.

title: Folger Tech FT-5 filament guide ("reverse bowden") brackets

description.text:
During initial testing with the FT-5, I noticed how the hotend movements are also dragging filament off the spool. Given the high travel speeds of the x-y carriage on an FT-5, I didn't feel it was a good idea to let the same movement also unwind a heavy filament spool at the same time.

I also own a Kossel, which has a a bowden setup where the extruder is mounted on the frame, a bowden tube feeds the filament to the hotend. For the FT-5, I didn't plan to move the extruder, but simply having a bowden tube still means that the distance from the spool to the hotend stay the same, regardless of the hotened carriage position.

So I made a clip to mount on the real, above where my spools are, with a 5mm pneumatic connector, connecting a standard PTFE tube long enough to reach from the mounting position to every possible position of the hotend carriage.

The PTFE tube runs to another pneumatic connector on the hotend carriage.
I wanted to have the pneumatic coupler as high as possible, to give some room to thread the filament into the extruder, and using the existing mounting screws at the top of the hotened carriage assembly. Lastly, I'm not a fan of the cable clips, so I included a simple bracket that I use with a zip tie to lash the cables to new bracket.

(Credit to this design which inspired mine: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1633674).

Printer:

FolgerTech FT-5

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2mm

Infill:

25%

Notes:

After printing, use a small drill to make sure the filament feed holes are wide enough to reduce friction. Use pliers and a little bit of persuasion to screw the 5mm pneumatic couplers into the openings on the two clips.

The rail bracket goes wherever you have your spools. I have mine in the middle of the front top rail, and above where the spool uncoils, so that there is a more or less straight path from the spool into the tube.

The hotend bracket goes on the top of the carriage using the existing screws. Just mount them the other way around (with the nyloc M3 nuts on the front). Use a zip tie on the left to secure your hotend wires into position.

title: Omnibot 2000 Arm Joint
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
Do you have an Omnibot 2000 robot - http://www.robotsandcomputers.com/robots/personal.php?filename=omnibot2k.htm - whose arm is just hanging limp at his side? More than likely, the problem is a broken arm joint. You can see where this common-failure part breaks in the second and third photos. I glued mine back together long enough to make a silicone mold from which I then cast a functional, albeit ugly, replacement years ago. Now that I have a 3D printer... why not use it for something useful?

This replacement is identical to the original with one exception - the top part is designed with more material to aide in strength. In the photos, I guess I should point out that the purple piece is the printed replacement whereas the grey piece is the original.

This is an impossible piece to locate and as far as I know, there are no other sources for either the joint itself or a 3D model. I am offering this to the public for the time being at no cost, but I reserve the right to pull this from the marketplace at any time. You are free to print this for your own use, but the sell of the file or the finished piece is strictly forbidden.

If you do find this model helpful, a tip would be greatly appreciated!

Printer:

Tevo Tarantula

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.3 is fine for function, but 0.1 is better for form

Infill:

at least 60% for strength

Notes:

Wall thickness should be set to 0.5mm with 2 walls to account for the top threads. If you can print the model with standard wall thickness and line count up to the flat portion with a reduced thickness beginning there, it'll produce a prettier print.

Sliced with Cura, the support material breaks away easily with XY-Distance set to 1mm.
The top hole is intentionally smaller than required. Drill and tap to the proper size after printing.

Top loops allow for supporting the stencil with a pencil or 5/16" dowel rod. They are 8 mm in diameter by design.

TOP: Antinazi.stl. Fairly self explanatory opposition to National Socialism. Contrary to some popular belief, National Socialism is not socialism, as it is based on a class society where workers do not control the means of production. It adopted the ancient swastika symbol, which has since become an umbrella symbol for governerance based on authoritarianism, capitalism, nationalism, racism, sexism and homophobia.

LEFT: antifaCircle.stl. This symbol was originally that of the German Iron Front, founded in 1931 by the Social Democratic Party. The three arrows stand for fascism, monarchism and communism. The history of the circle is mostly ignored today, as its primary users are anarchist and communist antifascists. The anti-communist arrow is commonly reinterpreted to refer to authoritarian communism, in contrast to to more voluntary systems of sharing such as councilism and anarcho-communism.

RIGHT: antifaLogo.stl and its variants. ANTIFA, short for Anti-Fascist Action was a movement that has started in Germany to oppose the re-emergence of fascist elements in society. The red and black flags stand for a union between anarchism and communism against the common enemy of fascism. Contrary to popular believe, ANTIFA is not an organization. It is fully decentralized, anyone can claim it. Rather it is a set of 4 obligations. If one is to call themselves ANTIFA, they must be committed to 1. tracking fascist activity, 2. opposing public far right organizing, 3. offering support to other anti-fascist activists such as medical support, 4. protecting the identities of antifascist activists against retribution by fascists or the state.
antifaLogoRed lets you spice it up with a red flag, or pink if you're hella queer and awesome.

Disclaimer: Keep it legal, use on private property only and with permission, obey the police/ violence inherent in the system, obey your bourgeois lords' commands. Do not witch hunt or harass people you think might be fascists/bigots, no vigilante stuff. If you're worried about people in your community, contact the people whom they may endanger. Be extremely careful around anyone you consider to be a potential fascist. Do not make yourself known to them.

remixed_from.author: habales
remixed_from.title: Pi Camera and Neopixel Ring Houseing

title: Raspberry Pi Camera Case w/ NeoPixel Ring (12 LED)
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
habales was the only model I could find that would house both a Pi Camera and a 12 LED NeoPixel ring. Only problem, it wouldn't fit the Prusa MK2 Camera Bed Mount - Higher Arm

http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2014167

So, after some massaging, I was able to come up with the same look, just add some legs to it so it could mount to the bed mount and increase its size a little so the walls were thicker to try and prevent light from bleeding out (didn't work like that with orange ABS). I also added the ability to print out a lens in a transparent filament. I would highly recommend PETG, or another transparent filament that can take high heat. That NeoPixel ring can get HOT! I would also recommend printing out the case in a filament that can take high heat. After about 2 minutes of a full on brightness, a case made with PLA failed miserably by the legs becoming useless and the camera falling off the mount, only to stop hitting the floor because of that weak ribbon cable & some 30awg silicone wire :/

I have since printed the case in ABS, the lens in PETG, and now when I run white camera light, I only use a brightness of 75. That is actually plenty bright for what the use is.

I created a python script that is rather crude just to get it working. You can find it at:
https://github.com/nixternal/Pi-Cam-NeoPixel

NOTE: The camera does snap in on to those posts and it holds it there, it isn't just floating. The lens is printed within the tolerances for my printer, so you may have to use a razor or something to shave it down a little to get a good fit.

Printer:

Prusa i3 MK2

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Doesn't Matter

Resolution:

.2

Infill:

25%

Notes:

ABS/PETG or something that can take heat, especially if you are using the brightness at full on in the Adafruit NeoPixel library (ie: full is 255, I run at 75 and it is plenty bright). If you run it at 75 or lower, then you can probably get away with using PLA

description.text:
Portrait of Livia

Roman, late Republic, mid-late 30 BC

"This portrait of Livia was created not long after her marriage to Emperor Augustus. As the first empress of Rome, Livia wanted her public image to embody all the virtues that the Romans valued in a woman, including "pudicita" (modesty) and "pietas" (respect). She also set a new fashion with her innovative nodus hairstyle, in which a section of hair is arranged in a roll over the forehead, while the rest of the hair is swept back in loose waves and secured in a bun at the nape of the neck."

Scan from Walters Museum in Baltimore

print_settings.Notes:: This took a nearly an hour to render on a 3.2GHz i7. The more "leaves" you add, the longer it will take.

description.text:
This OpenSCAD object is based on the same mechanism as my "sea growth." I adjusted the stalks to be like broad, pointed leaves, bunched together at the bottom. The result looked like a flower missing a central stalk -- or maybe the leaves around the stem of the flower -- and that suggested placing something in the middle. Rather than add to the object itself I thought a candle would look great there, so I carved out a cylinder to hold a candle.

I called it "tulip" as an analogy for that flower's leaves and not the flower itself.

At the height I've selected (4 inches) a 12-inch candle seems to fit perfectly (a shorter candle looks a bit too stubby to me).

OpenSCADers can add extra "leaves" beyond the 7 I have here by adjusting "n," but note that this will open a small hole in the bottom. Otherwise, varying between 3 and 11 all seems to produce useful results. I prefer odd numbers; even numbers are a little too symmetrical for me. I've added a 5-leave version of this object in yellow.

Printer Brand:

LulzBot

Printer:

Mini

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.2mm

Infill:

33%

Notes:

I printed this in translucent red PETG (well, the box says "magenta" but, really, it's as red as it appears in the photo).

This took a nearly an hour to render on a 3.2GHz i7. The more "leaves" you add, the longer it will take.

title: Flail from OMF2097
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
This one is a blast from the past! Harking from the retro DOS game OMF 2097, we did up a model of the iconic Flail bot with its chains printable and ready to go a'flailing!

Pieces have been sized down to fit most 3d printers and assembly on where the parts go are in the images attached to this model. The chain on Flail needs to be printed in a sequence which allows for you to loop them through each other while still being printed.

Instructions are attached for further information on how the pieces go together.

Most pieces may require support material, and works well printed at 0.2 or lesser layer height, 15-20% infill and with 3-5 shells.

Depending on your 3d printer and printing setting, you can expect to take around 40-50 hours for all the parts.

Have fun with this! =)

Support us on Patreon - https://www.patreon.com/FunbieStudios

description.text:
Based on the http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1749035 made by Kenneth Johansson "kenjo123", I decided to remake the ENTIRE staff, since the acrilic parts are really fragile as a junction staff.

The thing was printed with 25% infill, but you can do it with a little less or a bit more.

Since the bolt holes have really little tollerance, you will have to force them in, but this is also a good thing, once in they can't get out easily.

this was printed and is currently used in a functional 3D scanner from cowtech, the ciclop.

Please note, they only fit in the correct order, this was made on purpose.

print_settings.Notes:: Rotate the upper braces by 25° to fit the build plate and make sure you set your Slicer to 100% scale.

title: "Hulk" Frame Brace for the Anet A8

description.text:
Story

One of the Anet A8 biggest drawbacks is the lack of stability in the X-axis. The higher you print the more layers may shift or waves may occur on the printed object.
For this reason I designed popular brackets to reduce the motion in X-axis: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1872162
However they will not completely eliminate the issue.
I therefore came up with a more effective means of reducing / eliminating any X-axis motion on the printer.

Goals / Highlights
  • Eliminates any motion in x-axis direction.
  • Is adjustable to fit any frame misalignment's.
  • Can always be readjusted to compensate for a loosening frame due to vibrations.
  • Uses less filament compared to other designs.
  • Easy fits on a print bed.
Parts selection

Select files

  • "Hulk_Right_Top_Arm_wBracket_Leo_N.stl" and
  • "Hulk_Left_Top_Arm_wBracket_Leo_N.stl"

if you have my "Brackets" (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1872162) installed on your printer. The "Brackets" are not needed for the "Hulk" braces if you haven't already printed them.
You will want to open the holes by using a sharp knife. After the braces have been mounted use a 3.5mm drill and then secure the part with screw, washer and nut (see picture).

If you are not using the Brackets then use files

  • "Hulk_Right_Top_Arm_Leo_N.stl" and
  • "Hulk_Left_Top_Arm_Leo_N.stl"

for assembly.

Files

  • "Hulk_Right_Bottom_Support_Leo_N.stl" and
  • "Hulk_Left_Bottom_Support_Leo_N.stl"

will be need in either case.

Installation

You will need the following:

  • 2 x M3x20 - 22mm screws MAX!
  • 2 x M3 nuts
  • 2 x 3mm washers

To install each brace you will want to insert the nut into the upper brace and then place it into the lower holder. Next take the washer and screw and insert it into the assembly.
Remove the top screw on the lower acrylic support part on each side.
Now take the complete brace and start at the top by lodging the part to the acrylic frame and then push the lower frame brace onto the lower acrylic part. It should snap in.
Take the screws you removed earlier, optionally add washers and insert both screws to the lower acrylic supports.
The next step is to slowly and carefully turn the screw until the brace has a snug fit and the upper portion of the printer frame is no longer moving in X-axis.

Be very careful not to put too put any force on the frame by over tightening the screw!!

Please let me know if you have a problem with the design so I can improve it if necessary or you what new features to the design.

Also please post a picture with comments if you have made one.

Thanks.

Leo

Update 2017.05.25

Updated file "Hulk_Left_Bottom_Support_Leo_N" due to very little gap between the bottom support and the x-carriage stepper motor on some Anet frames.

Update 2017.05.28

Lengthened both Bottom_Support's by 0.2mm.

Update 2017.05.30

Removed holes on the bottom supports to avoid contact with the stepper motor if users
selected screws that are to long.

Update 2017.07.22

Updated both lower supports by reducing height of the mount that support the top braces by -2.0mm. Use the appropriate plates (1mm, 1.5mm or 2mm) included in the file section if your braces are still too loose. Place plate inside the bottom support (picture #4) for height adjustment.

Printer:

Anet A8

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

Your choice

Infill:

15%

Notes:

Use 0.8mm wall thickness.

You might need to use "Rafts" to avoid warping depending on your printer setup.

Rotate the upper braces by 25° to fit the build plate and make sure you set your Slicer to 100% scale.

comments.text:
Pictures superimpose screw-to-screw, rod-to-rod, label-to-label. The ONLY difference is WHITE Z-axis supports, mine being black.
My idea is that as it happens over and over again with the sizes of the power supply box the printers may have small lot-to-lot differences, sometimes even improvements, which are not reported in documentation. Anet already changed A8 specs "on the fly" in the past, this same forum is full of "variations on A8 Theme". Low-end DIY printers are NOT a world where you can demand strict industrial standards - they are beautiful for this, by the way.
No reason to turn aggressive or insulting, I think.
Peace! and thanks for counseling.

comments.text: A couple of questions:
comments.author: GrolarBear

comments.text:
The Hulk braces are designed to be used without the brackets for the intended frame stiffness.
However if the braces are already installed you have the advantage of fixating the hulk braces via the screws for additional secured mounting options.
If you have cracked frame pieces then be very careful when mounting the Hulk braces. You can easily put a lot of stress on the acrylic frame if they are over tightened.

comments.text: I've just ft these braces and found that if I tighten them at all it introduces wobble into my Y axis.  I had to loosen the braces right off and redo all the M8 nuts on the Y axis threaded rods to get it sitting solidly level again. On subsequently attempting to tighten the braces, I find any additional tension introduced into the system causes the feet of the front piece to lift off my workbench (again introducing wobble to the Y axis).  Starting to get the feeling my printer was doing pretty well without any additional bracing!  I think I may need to add Y axis braces before I can actually tighten my hulk braces..
comments.author: Shiftah

comments.text:
If you have any tension then you have over tightened the braces.
When you install them without the screws the upper arms should be "loose". Now turn the screws AND NO MORE until the upper arms are no longer loose and the upper portion of your frame can no longer move in x-axis direction. Any further turns on the screws will cause tension on the frame which is not necessary and you don't want!
comments.author: Shiftah

description.text:
This is a modular version of Josef's Y axis belt holder.

I decided to design this one to make unmounting the heat bed easier in case of possible PEI sheet replacement (http://manual.prusa3d.com/Guide/Replacing+the+PEI+sheet/133#_ga=1.105576833.343745215.1487835015).

By using this belt holder it's not necessary to loosen the screws, the heat bed is mounted to it's frame, but only remove the tension of the Y belt and simply pick the modular belt holder to pieces.

In addition if you decide to use MartinMajewski's great "Y-Frame Assembly Helper" (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1846654) it's easier to install the Y belt form the top with the heat bed installed later using that modular holder.

I printed both parts in different colours for better visibility

Important: Please follow the post-priniting hint!

EDIT (2017-03-24):
Added an enfordced version of the inner part

Printer:

Prus i3 Mk2

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.100

Infill:

20%

Important hint:

The design is very thight dimensioned to avoid any problems with printer calibration or impacts on printing quality. So it's recommended to slowly assemble and disassemble printed parts several times until they smooth sliding before installation to the printer.

description.text:
What happens when you take some stalks made from twisting, tapering extruded ellipses and have them bulge out and then taper together to a point? Well, this is what you get. With an overall shape of a stereotypical candle flame, what else can I call it?

This OpenSCAD object is my favorite at the moment. Like most of the others I've based on twisting and bending columns, it's made up of many thin slices stacked on top of each other and thus takes a while to render (17 minutes on my 3.2GHz i7). You can tweak the number of columns that make it up between 3 and 15 or so, though below 5 the bottom separates making it a bit hard to take off your build plate without a brim or raft.

A photo for a 9-column flame is also shown here. And I've been experimenting with forming an 11-column version of this around a cylinder and putting an LED unit inside. I'm still trying to find the best type of filament to do this that doesn't block most of the light.

Printer Brand:

LulzBot

Printer:

Mini

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.2mm

Infill:

33%

Notes:

The object in the photo was printed in red translucent PETG; it should print in just about anything. It looks great (more flame-like) in orange or yellow.

As noted, you may want to use a raft or brim if you reduce the number of columns below 5.

description.text: This stand has 3 holes because it is possible to use single, two or all three hoes to fix 10x10 mm square wooden profile. It is possible to mount camera, microphone, some light (flashlight, single or more). I found easier (and faster) to use available 10x10 mm square wooden profile, but you can make your own 3D printed profile... Right now I have no idea for which thing you will use and how long, so it is up to your imagination. Squares may be equal in length, or different lengths, depending of what you want. It is also decorative, but main goal is to be practical. PLA is the material of choice, but can be printed with many other materials. My personal setting is 212C on hotend, 50C on bed (or up to 70C), printing speed 20 mm/s or more. Infill is 10% for ordinary use, or increase infill for something heavier. Since 3D print is not so demanding, you may change all parameters.

title: JPN Extruder for CMYK+ colorprinting
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
The Joined PiNion Extruder, proposal for the multi/fullcolor printing.

Many concepts are based on the Bowden extruders. One drawback of the Bowden is a slag hysteresis when extrude/retract. This makes the accurate color mixing difficult.

Obviously placing 4-6 stepper motors next to print head would be problematic because of space and mass. BUT, why we would need the own motor for the each filament... I started to think if less is more.

To add actuator (e.g servo) controlled gearbox the one stepper motor could drive (in principle limitless) numerous filaments.

In this example there are 6 filaments e.g. for Cyan, Magenta, Yellow & Black and White & Transparent.

The concept is based on 3 sliding pinion gears (red arrows), controlled by servo. The pinions are two main gears wide so they can drive more than one filament at the same time. The primary pinion (next to motor) selects the left, right or both extruder main shafts.

(Obviously using the dog teeth gears selection will give even more flexibility to select any filament combination)

The filament is selected by moving the the small pinions to the position required. If needed the pinion can drive two parallel filaments/side at the same time.

The parallel drive will be useful when retract filaments. The colors will be mixed in the nozzle but simultaneous retract and direct drive allows precis control.

Newer design available, SS (Super Charged)
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2195351
