comments.text:
I actually once thought about a full-color delta printer design, but I scrapped it extremely early; I never got to thinking of how to manage the extrusion of 6 filament. I'm really glad that someone else has found/is finding a way to tackle this.
The only useful idea I really had that could apply to this was to use concentrated colored filaments (with natural in place of transparent) that could be mixed to achieve a perfect hue; the slicer would first determine the color, then add natural material until it met the required amount. The same could possibly be done with transparent, exchanging the warm white offset of natural for transparency.
comments.author: Jerimon

comments.text: If you look carefully you'll notice the Lego gears on the picture :-) I also make Lego PoC about the gearing.
comments.author: Jerimon

comments.text:
That is indeed one of the drawbacks for that type of gearbox; each gearbox has its own pros and cons, so it is key to check each one before throwing them out of the ring.
The LEGO gears are actually why I mentioned the usage in LEGO sets. The gearbox parts aren't in all Technic sets, so I didn't want to assume that you had them to test with.
Remember to use helical gears in the later prototypes to reduce noise, increase tooth contact, and smooth transitions. There's a reason why they use them in the ever-shifting gearboxes of cars.
comments.author: jpnurro

comments.text: Lovely idea - has this been discussed anywhere else?  With the design as shown, I'm not sure where the pressure wheels would go... these need to push the filament against the extruder wheel teeth to make it grip properly...
comments.author: rogerlucas

comments.text:
Yes, I created a tread:
http://www.thingiverse.com/groups/engineering/topic:13202
comments.author: rogerlucas

comments.text: OK, but I must be misunderstanding something then.  On the extruder designs that I have seen, the pressure wheels are pushed by springs and must be released to allow the filament to be loaded or removed.  I can't see how that would work with this design.  How would you load and unload the filaments?
comments.author: jpnurro

comments.text:
Those cheapest printers (like mine) has no sprint or moving parts, just a driver gear and a wheel. The filament goes between those. Changing the filament I have to retrace the filament like 35mm but it works. In this set-up you don't change the filament the often because this is full color set-up.
The spring loaded wheels could be placed by pushing the wheels downwards between the left and right filament lines, I think.
comments.author: rogerlucas

comments.text: I think this is a wonderful idea! If I can contribute I will :)
comments.author: AcrimoniousMirth

comments.text:
Thank you! Obviously there are some calculation to do as well the machinery. SW is needed as well to control the gear box & colormixing
Like which kind of axles carry to forces but are compact. Extruder's heat balance might be the issue to control. I put 3 heat rods a round.
comments.author: AcrimoniousMirth

comments.text:
Yes, it's a challenging setup but theoretically plausible. Software I see as the largest challenge!
If the gears are supported properly on either side then you can get away with pretty thin axles, you'll probably want a decent modulus, Inventor or Solidworks would be able to auto-generate gears as a guide. It takes a 13Ncm motor to push 1.75mm filament if memory serves, some simple ratio calculations should work through fine.
I'm guessing you know all that already, I'm more thinking "aloud".
comments.author: jpnurro

comments.text: I don't even know what I don't know, all new info here
comments.author: AcrimoniousMirth

comments.text: Putting your gear diameters and some other values through with the input motor torque through a bending stress calculation will give you said bending stress. You can then use this to choose a suitable material or check an existing gear's suitability. I have a spreadsheet for this. Nerd intensifies
comments.author: jpnurro

comments.text: I really like this idea and would like to work with you on getting a concept working

comments.text: Excellent, this has risen up a lot of positive feedback. I wanted to publish this here so that all possible knowledge will come in to good use.

description.text:
This is an upgrade for https://www.amazon.com/dp/B01LWBLVYS and other cheap CNC engravers to allow for a larger 52mm motor https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B00MN7WERA and Z axis linear bearings https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B00ED150S4

Note: This is not a recommendation for any of the above products, buying anything that inexpensive has it's drawbacks, but that is why we have 3D printing.

The OpenScad file has variables that should be useful for upgrading other similar CNC machines. You will need the OpenSCAD version >= 2016.XX to modify/render the vacuum adapter (I think this version is only available as a development snapshot).

Note: You will need to upgrade the Z axis stepper a bit for the additional tool weight. Also, take note of the reconfiguration of the CNC frame to keep the motor centered in the build area.

Update: Added extra clearance from Z axis frame and experimental vacuum ports (vacuum attachment isn't well tested, needs a boot / brushes)

title: Printrbot Plus- Polakium type Direct Drive Extruder Platform and Fan Shroud.

description.text:
These files will create an extruder mounting platform and cooling fan shroud to be fitted to the Polakium Engineering or my own X axis carriage for the Printrbot Plus Ver 1. The extruder is of the 1.75mm fliament variety fitted with 0.4mm nozzle. The extruder I used for this design was created from parts available from RobotDigg.com. Here is a list of the components. Obviously they are generic for the most part and can be acquired anywhere. Single Extruder Bar Mount
MK7 Aluminum Thermal Core
MK7 Molded Drive Block
PTFE Liner Thermal Barrier Tube
NEMA 17 17HS3001-20B Stepper Motor
MK8 0.4mm Nozzle 40mm 12 volt fan. Rev 1G fan shroud has additional channeling for cooling air to circulated around the stepper motor further dissipating excess heat.

title: SW - TIE/D Defender
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
The TIE/D Defender was the latest and most powerful of all TIE Fighters
Introduced in the Mission Pack of the PC Game TIE Fighter it quickly replaced the Avenger.

I know there is a official version of it from FFG but I neither liked that nor the blueprint version it is based on because it is some sort of unrealistic.
The Defender is faster than everything else, has strong shields, a hyperdrive, a tractor beam and two warhead launchers, but no room for that. The original PC Version included a hull to carry all that but the FFG Model did not.
So I made my own version based on the original PC version and some inspirations I got from the even better version from fractalsponge.

model 1 is the simple model
model 2 includes a pin holder a support bar in the wings to prevent deformation while printing (the wings had that problem in the first test print)

scale 1:270 to match the rest of my show-case models
Print successful, photo will be added
